reviewText: This is one of the best Indie games I have ever played, it's very hard so don't expect something easy, it reminds me the most of the old NES games where you probably had to lose 1,000 times before you figured out what you were doing wrong, but for that reason I love it, and then just beating the game isn't enough, which can be done in under an hour (my current run definitely agrees with this) but then you have the leaderboard to keep you hooked, every death loses points, every second, loses points and every kreb gains points, it's possible to get some pretty insane scores and to this day I never feel as if I've done my all time best run.  this game takes skill, brains, and a lot of determination, but trust me if you're up for the challenge this is well worth your money
voteText: 39 of 63 people (62%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I'm old by steam standards.  I remember drooling over pong, Zork and coding my own games in from magazines ... yep for those of you under 40 this was how we got games. I don't have twitch speed and I need controls to be accurate.  Keep that in mind with my review.

Pro:
Short
Adequate graphics
Tons of levels
Soundtrack
Cards

Cons:
Controls are ... not accurate to a point of rage quit
Debate on if achieves are working
After 30 min it's boring, unless this is really your type of game
Price

Other:
OK there has been some comparisons to super meat boy.  I think that's not fair. SMB is a great example of the genre.  This is, if the controls get fixed, an adequate example at best (sucks with the current controls).  if your looking for SMB, go play that. If you want to try a game in that genre, with control issues, grab this one (on sale)


Overall:
6/10 (+2 soundtrack, -1 price, -3 controls) = 4/10
Get this game at 75% if you have super twitch speed, 90% off if your a normal human, 100% off if your old like me.

reviewText: Short, but really fun and addictive. This game took me little over an hour of gameplay to complete, but it was really fun and challenging while it lasted. There were moments when I thought I'd never get past the area I was stuck on, but it had that sort of 'hard but not impossible' feel about the game. The soundtrack was a real nice addition as well and sounded reminiscent of the 16-Bit days. There's no telling how long the game will take you to complete, but there were certainly some challenging aspects of the game. In the right hands it could occupy a lot of your time, but either way I'd recommend it as a fun and addictive time passer.

reviewText: Honestly, Its not a hardcore game, it does not live up to the name of super meat boy, its a fun game to a point, but the floaty controls, without the precision i expect from a intense game, I want to be able to blame myself for dying, not bouncing off a wall or making that one pixel game in a time limit when I just float by it and bounce off the wall dying, fun game, but overall not what I expected

reviewText: Fun game, but can be really frustrating, so best played in short bursts.  The  SURVIVED (i.e. You Win) screen  tells me I played for 114 minutes and died 433 times, but it honestly felt a lot longer than that.\n\nThis is one of those twitch/punishment platformers, though it's not exactly a platformer since you control a floating ball that can move about freely without worrying about gravity.  The goal is to make your way to the end of each of the levels without dying.  There are no checkpoints, and but the levels is pretty short.  Unlike other twitch platformers, you have a healthbar and most hazards will not kill you in one hit - being squished between moving walls/ is the common exception.  Your health also decreases over time, so it serves as an implicit time limit even in the relatively few levels which don't have a huge moving wall (or Boss) chasing you.  Boosting (i.e. running") makes the health decrease much faster
date: so it's best used only when needed.\n\nEach level has collectible "krebs"
recommended: and getting all of these greatly increases the challenge
hoursPlayed: but they are only useful for high scores and achievements.  After the first few levels
voteText: I stopped even trying collecting them all and focused instead on just surviving.\n\nThe game is HARD
helpfulPercent: and controls take a lot of getting used to.  The keyboard offers the most precise controls
votesHelpful: but unfortunately a bug keeps you from being able to boost (speed up) while moving diagonally up-left
votesTotal: which makes a few levels impossible.  So yeah
votesFunny: that's definitely a minus.  But the rest of the game makes up for it in my opinion.   The gameplay

column18: and the soundtrack is great.  After finishing it

reviewText:
horrible, frustrating, repetitive, irritating, and overall just a painful exercise in tedium.

did you love all those oldschool platform games on your console with the boss fights and then the scene where you had to run to escape the exploding level as fast as you could dodging falling walls and crushing traps before your character died?

how about an entire game where all you do is rush through the level racing against time as walls close in and gears and spikes get in your way?

yeah.. it's like someone decided to make a whole game out of 1 single aspect of platform games.

avoid if you have any interest in storylines or interesting gameplay mechanics.

reviewText: Controls like balls and character bumps off of everything constantly. Not to mention that the hitbox is nowhere near accurate. Stupid gimmick to artificially lengthen gameplay ruins the pacing of the game. Great soundtrack and is aesthetically pleasing to look at despite the horrible controls.

reviewText: KRUNCH is a fantastic game. The retro styling and the way you control the character reminds very much of Space Tripper and Astro Tripper. The game only requires use of the arrows keys and one button, but in this simple control system lies a game of great depth of precision gameplay. Cracking music throughout and it suits the game perfectly. Its not as well known a game as it should be, so its not too hard to get fast times on the leaderboards of individual levels. Highly recommended.

reviewText: KRUNCH is an amazing game. Do you like a challenge? Do you like feeling rewarded when you work really hard? Well then KRUNCH is for you. This game has amazing old school graphics and is a ton of fun to play. *** This game is a 10/10 ***

reviewText:
For what little good I can say about Krunch I can say this: It has good music.

Everything else needs to be revisited... especially the controls. It's not that the controls are atrocious or impossible to master but rather the fact that the whole game revolves around avoiding monsters and obstacles with the only option to speed up, if the controls are not well adjusted and feel bulky players will turn their heads from the game and never look back. If the controls are to stay as they are then the game should take a different approach and maybe have less envirenmental hazards, more ennemies and a way to fight back.

Something else that I personally find undesirable is the visual style. The graphics give the impression that they didn't put too much efforts into the character design and the monochromatic abuse just underline this lack of savoir faire. Some games can pull this kind of stunt admirably and end up being enjoyable and fun to play (Don't Look Back" or "Today I Die" are but two exemples of this) but with Krunch it just force me to look twice at everything and I end up wondering "Why is my character's vision so impaired... is it because he's some kind of robot?" or "That message was important but it looked just like it was part of the environment... who wrote it?" and I have played the early games of yore on my pc junior and my atari 3600 and never have graphical limitation been excused for poor visuals and a great exemple of what i'm saying would be "Out Of This World" since the game was limited in term of graphics like you can't comprehend and they still managed to deliver something that you can fell conected to when you play it to a point that you actually want to finish the game. Krunch visuals combined with the poor controls just make me want to never play the game again.

The game developers are relatively new in the game making business so
date: if you're listening... Egoraptor youtube channel
recommended: go watch his SEQUELITIS videos. You might learn a thing or two."

reviewText:
Man what an amazing thrill i had with this game, from an artistic proportion mixed with a retro feeling.

This game is a call back to the old gaming eras back when games used to be hard and rewarding.

I was compelled to continue playing, this game may punish your mistakes just like Super meat boy but it is very forgiving and it is easy to learn and perfect.

Overall this game was intense to the very end, i had more fun than i had problem, my only gripe with this game would be that it felt abit short so i hoped for a Expansion or sequel because this game does deserve one. Big props for the creators.

Highly recomend this game!

reviewText: KRUNCH is a fantastic indie action game, which plays like a precision racing game and brings to mind challenging platformers such as VVVVVV and Super Meat Boy. You will die a lot, but you'll learn from your mistakes, and soon you'll be zooming gracefully through the dangerous traps and enemies! Throw in an awesome soundtrack and visually appealing retro graphics, and KRUNCH makes for an excellent addition to your indie collection! Not to mention the devs have been nothing but friendly and very easy to communicate with!
voteText: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
General:
Do you like challenges? Then KRUNCH is for you. I would put it in the same box with the VVVVVV and Super Meat Boy because at some point it takes a lot of patience to get through the levels. This is by no mean a casual game so expect some cursing and sweating along the way.

While there are no checkpoints, levels are pretty short so you can easily play the game in 5 minutes break, which is great. Controls may seem a bit clunky at the start but you get used to them quite fast. Game offers 4 themes, each specializing in different kind of traps, mind breaking yet cool traps. Each one of them ends with a huge challenge - run run run and don't hit the corner" type of a level.

Replay value:
For competing type of a person there is a highscore you can climb up to or you can earn some extra Achievements if you want extra challenges. Yes
date:
there are reasons to play this game over and over again.

Bugs/Crashes encountered: None

Overall: 4-5 (on a scale from 1-5)
Graphic: 5 (Really nice pixel art with great effects)
Music & Sound effects: 5 (Music works just great)
Gameplay: 4 (Gameplay is really fun but sometimes you'll just get deadlocked with all the bumping)
Other: 4 (Unclean interface - how to toggle fullscreen? How to return to the main menu from the game?)
Conclusion: Yes
recommended: you should BUY this game if you like challenges."
voteText: true

reviewText:
Krunch is the game you say 'one more level' to. Then you do five more and try to think about stopping—yet you just keep blazing through levels and tryin' again. Its hard, but not impossible by any means. This is one of those games for the people who thrive off the rush of finally getting that hard thing down(it may take you fifty tries, but its all the more sweet!).

Yes, the hitboxes can seem ridiculous but its a pixel game. And awesome pixel game with a great soundtrack and visuals.

Krunch makes it pretty clear its your fault when you lose—and when you win. Krunch is krack.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game, But I can't. The reason that Super Meat Boy" (Krunch often getting compare to SMB) is so damn good is because the controls are incredibly presice. I can't say the same for Krunch. The control of your character is very
recommended: floaty. Your chatacter has too much weightlessness and momentum. making precise turning and timing way more difficult that they need to be. IE in SMB if you fked up it was your fault because you have such clear control over your character. Here not so much. Also SMB have very clear and obvious hitboxes on the traps which men't you could avoid them. Here the spining saw traps (that are circles) have square hit boxes so you can be quite clearly not touching them and get bounched back and killed for no good reason. When i played SMB i would get frusterated at myself for losing

reviewText: KRUNCH is a game about guiding flying orbs through a series of mazes, with the goal of escaping the factory. There are around 100 levels divided between 4 zones with a boss encounter at the end. Speed and precision are required for sucess. The soundtrack and visuals add greatly to the game's appeal. The controls take a bit to get use to, but once you do they are fine. It is a bit short, but if you aim to collect some the achievements, you will spend more time in the game.\n\nOriginally I didn't think I was going to like the game very much, but I returened for the card drops and ended up having a great time.

reviewText:
NOTE: THIS REVIEW WOULD BE NEGATIVE IF I’VE BOUGHT THIS GAME FOR FULL (10€) PRICE.

Gameplay is really simple. You represent a ball and try to avoid obstacles to navigate to level’s exit. Ball can speed up, but it drains life. Level design is fine, it usually take some time to remember where traps are, after that every level is beatable. Unfortunately your biggest enemy is broken hitboxes. Sometimes you’ll hit the wall (or spikes) even if you should be fine. This nearly kill it for me, however I need at least to mine all trading cards. After one hour, or so, I started to enjoy the game. Soundtrack is above average and levels are challenging but not frustrating (but you need to accept the broken hitboxes).

And… it took me just about two hours to complete the game. Wtf? I expected more content. Certainly not worth 10 Euro.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Control an ugly ball thing that flies/floats through ugly, hazard-filled corridors while various timers (walls closing in, health slowly declining) throw on the pressure. It's designed for speed-running by masochists so it is possible to get quite far in a very short time.

It's a hard game, compounded by the painfully floaty controls. Those hazards that do not result in instant death are liable to trap or bounce you back to a death marginally slower but just as inevitable, so anything other than control perfection is enough to relegate it to the trash pile. (Note on this point that keyboard seems substantially better than gamepad, though.)

As if that weren't enough, it's also ugly -- character, monster and environment designs are both uninspired and unattractive. It feels like 8-bit chic chosen for cheapness rather than artistic vision.

Ultimately the real problem is that it's just not fun. I like hard games and these kinds of graphics should give me a nostalgic thrill, but there is just no joy to be found here.

I turned Krunch off after the first boss, and I hated it so much that I went back in just to get a long enough playtime that Steam would let me post this review. It's the worst gaming experience I have had in years.
